Graphical abstract This work introduces phenanthroline metal complexes for electrode modification, forming nanocapsules that mitigate volume expansion, enhance catalysis, facilitate ion transport, and suppress dendrite growth by creating protective anode layers during charging. Aqueous Cu-S batteries (ACSBs) offer a promising energy storage solution by leveraging the unique redox properties of Cu2+ ions, enabling high theoretical capacities through a four-electron transfer reaction. These advantages are coupled with inherent safety and low cost, making ACSBs a compelling alternative to traditional batteries. However, the practical application of ACSBs is hindered by the low conductivity of sulfur and the high energy barrier associated with phase transitions, which limit material utilization and reaction kinetics. Herein, we propose for the first time a multifunctional organic small-molecule polysulfide catalyst, Zn(phen)S6, and successfully convert them into nanocapsules that are homogeneously dispersed on the cathode surface, effectively increasing the catalytic active sites. Moreover, this complex undergoes reversible reactions during cycling, releasing zinc ions that form a dense protective layer on the anode during charging, effectively inhibiting dendrite growth. Meanwhile, Zn(phen)S6 interacts with Cu2+ ions to undergo an in-situ solid-state transformation into a novel catalyst, [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n . This catalyst not only accelerates electron transfer but also serves as an ion transport channel, significantly boosting reaction kinetics. This battery demonstrates exceptional stability, retaining 97.7% of its initial capacity after 1200 cycles at a high current density of 10 A g−1. Furthermore, it maintains an impressive capacity of 1157 mAh g−1 after 1600 cycles at 20 A g−1. This work provides pivotal insights into the design and application of molecular catalysts, opening new pathways for advancing Cu-S battery technologies. Keywords Nano-engineered copper polysulfide Solid-state transformation Anode protection Ion transport channel Multifunctional 1 Introduction In response to the global imperative for renewable energy sources and energy security, the development of high-performance, cost-effective, and sustainable energy storage solutions is crucial. In this context, aqueous multivalent metal-ion batteries, particularly those that utilize cations capable of multiple electron transfers such as Cu2+, Zn2+, and Al3+ [1–5], have drawn significant attention due to their potential for achieving higher specific capacities and energy densities. However, their application is constrained by the narrow electrochemical stability window (∼1.23 V) of aqueous electrolytes, which poses challenges to maximizing battery voltage and energy density. Sulfur, a low-cost and abundant nontoxic material, exhibits a theoretical discharge specific capacity of up to 1675 mAh g−1 through a two-electron transfer process [6,7]. Leveraging this advantage, aqueous zinc-sulfur batteries have garnered extensive research interest. However, the unique tetrahedral coordination of zinc and sulfur atoms in the discharge product, ZnS, differs markedly from common discharge products like CuS and Li2S. The complex crystal structure and atomic arrangement of ZnS complicate the rupture of Zn–S bonds and rearrangement of surface atoms, thereby impeding the reversible transformation from ZnS back to sulfur, which limits the performance and lifespan of the battery [8,9]. Copper plays a pivotal role in electrochemical energy storage due to its abundant natural reserves, low cost, and well-developed processing techniques. The unique redox properties of Cu2+ not only allow it to serve as a charge carrier but also enable its reduction to Cu+ through additional redox processes, contributing extra electrons to the electrochemical storage system. Consequently, aqueous Cu-S batteries (ACSBs) could theoretically achieve much higher capacity through a four-electron transfer reaction, significantly surpassing traditional two-electron systems. However, the low electrical conductivity of sulfur, along with the high activation energy required for its phase transition, restricts the effective utilization of active materials and slows down the reaction kinetics [10]. On the other hand, the growth of copper dendrites is primarily attributed to uneven nucleation, which arises from the initial uneven distribution of Cu2+ ions. Furthermore, due to the “tip effect”, local current density increases during the charging process, causing copper ions to preferentially accumulate and deposit in these regions, thus accelerating dendrite formation. This dendritic growth may eventually penetrate the separator, leading to internal short circuits and posing risks to the safety and performance of the battery [11–13]. To address the issues outlined above, current research has primarily focused on the combination of sulfur with functionalized carbon materials. The objective is to leverage the high electron conductivity of carbon materials to counterbalance the poor conductivity of sulfur and its discharge products, as well as to mitigate the volumetric expansion of sulfur during charge-discharge cycles [14,15]. However, the nonpolar feature of these carbon materials is insufficient to modulate the redox kinetics of sulfur. Inspired by the use of catalytic materials in lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, metal-based catalysts [16–19] and redox mediators [20–23] are now considered promising candidates for accelerating electrochemical reaction kinetics, which facilitate the electrochemical reactions during battery charging and discharging. In the light of this, we synthesized a multifunctional catalytic material, the phenanthroline-hexasulfido-zinc(II) complex, Zn(phen)S6. The complex was successfully nano-engineered into a capsular structure and uniformly dispersed across the cathode surface, effectively mitigating volumetric expansion and increasing the catalytic active sites. Additionally, this complex undergoes reversible reactions during the charging and discharging processes, thereby enhancing the electrochemical activity within the battery and contributing to additional electrochemical capacity. Simultaneously, during the charging process, Zn2+ ions in the electrolyte are deposited onto the copper anode. Through a displacement reaction, copper is uniformly deposited, which enhances the stability of the electrode, and significantly enhances the cycle life of the Cu-S battery. Moreover, in the CuSO4 electrolyte, Zn(phen)S6 crystals interact with Cu2+ ions and undergo an in-situ transformation into a catalyst, [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n , which exhibits excellent electrochemical activity. This crystal not only undergoes redox reactions to provide additional electrons but also functions as an ion transport channel, thereby improving reaction kinetics. In existing studies, the aqueous Cu-S cathode transformation process has been limited to S → CuS ↔ Cu2S. Interestingly, the reaction between Zn(phen)S6 and Cu2S induces the formation of a previously unreported copper polysulfide phase, Cu x S y , expanding the scope of Cu-S chemistry and potentially enhancing battery performance. We compounded Zn(phen)S6 with sulfur and the conductive agent Ketjen black (KB) to prepare a Zn(phen)S6/KB/S composite material and systematically evaluated its electrochemical performance. Results indicate that even under an ultra-high current density of 20 A g−1, this composite material can maintain a high reversible capacity of 1157 mAh g−1 and a lifespan exceeding 1600 cycles, showcasing its substantial potential as a cathode material for Cu-S batteries. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structural characterization of the Zn(phen)S6 As depicted in Fig. 1 (a), a mixture of sublimated sulfur, zinc powder, and phenanthroline was refluxed in dimethylformamide (DMF) at high temperatures. Following this process, an orange-red filtrate was obtained, which was then left to stand for two days and subsequently purified through washing to yield golden-yellow crystals of Zn(phen)S6 (CCDC: 1242143) [24]. The crystal structure of the Zn(phen)S6 complex, along with its powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectrum, is shown in Fig. 1(b). The Zn atom at the center of the compound coordinates tetrahedrally with two sulfur and two nitrogen atoms. A single zinc atom, together with an S6 2− chain, forms a heptagonal ring, with an average S–S bond length within the chain being 2.048 Å. The XRD experimental values correspond closely with simulated values, indicating that the complex possesses high purity following process optimization. The morphology of Zn(phen)S6 crystals was examined using both scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 1(c and d), the crystals exhibit irregular cubic shapes with smooth surfaces. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping (Fig. 1e) confirmed the presence of Zn, S, and N elements within the crystals. Fig. S1(a) presents the ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectrum of the complex, in DMF solution. Phenanthroline exhibits an absorption peak at 267 nm, while Zn(phen)S6 shows a maximum absorption peak at 275 nm. After the formation of the complex, the conjugated system increases, resulting in a redshift of the wavelength, attributable to o-phenanthroline acting as a ligand in the complex. The infrared spectrum (Fig. S1b) displays an S–S stretching vibration peak at 473 cm−1, corroborated by the Raman spectrum (Fig. S1c) with a S–S stretching at 465 cm−1, indicating the presence of phenanthroline and S–S bonds in the compound [24]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the surface composition of Zn(phen)S6 crystals (Fig. S1d–g) confirms the composition of the complex consisting of Zn, C, H, N, and S elements (Fig. S1d). Fig. S1(e) demonstrates a double peak fit for the central Zn2+ in the complex at binding energies of 1044.60 and 1021.55 eV for Zn 2p [25,26]. The S 2p XPS spectrum in Fig. S1(f) shows a double peak fitting corresponding to bridging sulfur (164.34/163.26 eV) and terminal sulfur (162.73/161.85 eV) [27]. Additionally, the crystal structure of Zn(phen)S6 exhibits a low Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area of approximately 11.29 m2 g−1, with most pores being less than 20 nm (Fig. S1h). Fig. S1(i) displays the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) thermogram of more than 58.8% of the compound remaining undecomposed. This indicates that the compound exhibits irregular decomposition behavior and demonstrates significant stability. 2.2 Electrochemical performance and mechanistic study of Zn(phen)S6/KB in Cu-S batteries Based on the above characterizations, the successfully synthesized Zn(phen)S6/KB was utilized as the cathode material and assembled with copper foil into coin cells for electrochemical performance testing. To ensure a more uniform dispersion of the crystals, isopropanol (IPA) solution was utilized during the cathode fabrication process (Fig. S2), successfully transforming bulk crystals into nano-capsular structures (Fig. S3). The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Cu-Zn(phen)S6 half-cell, shown in Fig. 2 (a), display excellent reversibility with almost overlapping curves after the initial cycle. The performance of the Cu-Zn(phen)S6 half-cell (Fig. 2b, c) demonstrates exceptional rate capability with capacities of 1038.8, 983.6, 954.2, 911.6, and 802.2 mAh g−1 at current densities of 0.5, 1, 3, 5, and 10 A g−1, respectively, based on the active mass of Zn(phen)S6. The cycling performance of the Cu-Zn(phen)S6 half-cell (Fig. S4) exhibits a high initial capacity of 1018.5 mAh g−1 with an excellent capacity fade rate of 0.054% over 400 cycles at 1 A g−1. At a higher current density of 3 A g−1, the Zn(phen)S6 cathode maintains stable cycling performance with a capacity of 877 mAh g−1 after 700 cycles (Fig. 2d). In practical applications, the mass of Zn(phen)S6 crystals used as a catalytic material is substantially lower than that in half-cell configurations. After reducing the areal density of the material, even at an increased current density of 5 A g−1, the specific capacity of the Cu-Zn(phen)S6 half-cell was enhanced to1228 mAh g−1 (Fig. 2f), maintaining stable performance over more than 500 cycles, which significantly exceeds the performance observed at higher loadings. To directly observe the discharge state of the Cu-Zn(phen)S6 half-cell (Fig. 2e), a visual liquid cell was assembled. It was observed that as the depth of discharge increased, the color of the solution remained nearly unchanged. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) testing of the electrolyte after discharge revealed the presence of Zn2+ ions in the solution at a concentration of 233.3 mg L−1, which can be attributed to the gradual release of Zn2+ from the Zn(phen)S6 cathode during discharge. To further investigate the behavior of Zn2+ ions post-release, SEM and elemental mapping were conducted on the anodes of Cu-Zn(phen)S6/KB/S and Cu-KB/S coin cells after five charge cycles under identical conditions. In the Cu-Zn(phen)S6/KB/S half-cell, a uniform distribution of zinc was observed on the copper foil in contact with the cathode (Fig. S5a) as well as along other peripheral areas (Fig. S5b). In contrast, on bare copper foil, heterogeneous nucleation led to the formation of large protrusions (Fig. S6a), whereas the Zn-Cu foil showed a relatively smooth surface (Fig. S6b). This finding suggests that the presence and deposition of Zn2+ ions facilitate a co-deposition process with copper, effectively suppressing the growth of copper dendrites and thereby enhancing the cycling stability of the battery. The structural stability of the Zn(phen)S6 electrode material during cycling was investigated using SEM, which showed that after 700 cycles at 3 A g−1, the crystal structure was changed to a stacked, flake-like arrangement (Fig. S7), suggesting a transformation in the crystal structure. Ex situ XRD patterns during the charge-discharge process of the Zn(phen)S6 electrode (Fig. 2g) reveal characteristic peaks of new compound [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n initially. Upon discharge, following the breaking of sulfur chains, only Cu2S peaks were detected, indicating the achievement of sulfur pre-conversion. During subsequent charging, peaks corresponding to copper-sulfur clusters appeared sequentially, leaving a distinct CuS peak. During this process, Zn(phen)S6 demonstrated reversibility, along with highly reversible transformation reactions occurring between Cu2S and CuS. The formation of [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n is attributed to the interaction between Zn(phen)S6 and Cu2+. This is because, although both Cu2+ and Zn2+ are divalent metal ions, Cu2+ has a 3d 9 electronic configuration whereas Zn2+ has a 3d 10 configuration. The partially occupied 3d orbitals of Cu2+ and its smaller ionic radius result in higher charge density and a stronger ligand field effect. Consequently, Cu2+ exhibits a stronger ability to coordinate with the nitrogen atoms of phenanthroline compared to Zn2+ [28]. To investigate the formation mechanism of [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n (Fig. S8), this study initially confirmed the stability of the complex in air and water. After 24 h of exposure, no significant changes were observed, demonstrating its excellent chemical stability. To further eliminate the influence of pH, the crystal was immersed in solutions of ZnSO4 and CuSO4 at the same concentration. In the ZnSO4 solution, the crystal remained unchanged. However, in the CuSO4 solution, the crystal underwent a color transformation from golden yellow to reddish-brown and finally to purple-black over time, indicating that Cu2+ significantly affects the chemical properties of the crystal. The XRD pattern of the final transformation products (Fig. S9a) includes Cu9S5, S, [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n , and Zn(phen)S6. After soaking the final transformation products in carbon disulfide, UV testing revealed an absorption peak at 380 nm corresponding to sulfur (Fig. S9b). Infrared testing of the purified transition states (TS) and final states (FS) (Fig. S9c) showed the presence of ν(S–S) stretching vibrations in the transition state, while these were absent in the final state, which instead displayed a νS=O characteristic peak, corresponding to the infrared spectra of the newly formed complex [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n . The structure at final state appears in-situ growth of [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n on the surface of Zn(phen)S6 crystals. Thus, the reaction mechanism on the cathode during the rest phase (Scheme 1 ) can be summarized by the following formula. Elemental mapping images (Fig. S10) of the FS and TS analyze the distribution of Cu, S, and N elements, corroborating the aforementioned observations. Based on this mechanism, Zn(phen)S6 crystals were dissolved in DMF, and the CuS/Cu2S were left to react in the solution, resulting in the CuS-containing solution changing from yellow to pale blue, while the Cu2S-containing solution transitions from yellow to reddish-brown and eventually colorless (Fig. S11a). XRD characterization (Fig. S11b, c) showed that the redox reactions between Zn(phen)S6 and CuS/Cu2S partially oxidized CuS to S and Cu2S to CuS and S, and transformed Zn(phen)S6 to [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n . After soaking the two mixtures in carbon disulfide, the resultant S absorption peaks were tested (Fig. S11d). Surprisingly, the phenomena observed during the reaction between Zn(phen)S6 and Cu2S resemble the oxidation process of polysulfides. To investigate this, we recorded the oxidation phenomenon in real-time (Fig. 3 a) and employed in situ UV-vis spectroscopy (Fig. 3b) to examine the chemical changes in the filtrate following complete reaction. Notably, during the oxidation process, the color of the filtrate gradually transitioned from light to dark, with the strongest absorption peak appearing at approximately 450 nm. The emergence of this absorption peak indicates a significant change in the composition of the solution. Additionally, as the reaction progressed, the solution became colorless, and precipitates were observed, which may be associated with the formation of new substances or phase transitions of existing materials. Subsequent XRD analysis of the precipitate revealed diffraction peaks that closely match those of the standard sulfur phase, thereby confirming the presence of sulfur in the precipitate (Fig. S12). Due to the lack of significant changes observed in the visualization of the liquid battery, in order to further explore the conversion mechanism of the Cu-S battery, we employed in-situ UV-vis spectroscopy to study the chemical changes in Cu-KB/S and Cu-Zn(phen)S6/KB/S electrolytes. First, by testing the absorption peaks of CuSO4 electrolytes at different concentrations, we observed that as the concentration decreased, the absorption peaks exhibited both blue and red shifts (Fig. S13). Notably, under the same test conditions, the absorption peak attributed to CuSO4 during the discharge process of Cu-KB/S gradually increased (Fig. 4 a), which we speculate is due to the release of copper ions from the anode. However the corresponding absorption peak enhancement after Zn(phen)S6 loading is far more than that of pure sulfur control sample (Fig. 4b). In addition, we compared the disassembled results of aqueous and organic electrolyte button cells after three cycles and found that the separator of the Zn(phen)S6-loaded cathode exhibited a reddish-brown color (Fig. S14a), similar to the phenomenon observed on the separator of the pure sulfur electrolyte in the organic system (Fig. S14b). This phenomenon is similar to the previously unreported oxidation behavior of Cu x S y . To verify the presence of copper polysulfides, we assembled a visual liquid battery using DMF-Cu(OTF)2 organic electrolyte under an N2 atmosphere and performed in-situ UV-vis analysis. As shown in Fig. 3(c), during the first discharge, the electrolyte in the beaker cell gradually changed from the initial clear blue to green. The in-situ UV-vis spectra of the electrolyte during charging showed a significant oxidation of absorption peaks, almost identical to the phenomenon observed in the filtrate from the Zn(phen)S6-Cu2S reaction (Fig. 3d). Based on the above analysis results, we speculate that Zn(phen)S6 may induce the formation of copper polysulfides Cu x S y and propose the possible conversion mechanism during the discharge process. S → CuS → Cu x S y → Cu2S After briefly forming copper polysulfide, it is oxidized into sulfur and copper ions. The moderate increase of Cu2+ ions in the electrolyte enhances the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte, thereby increasing the conduction rate of electrons and ions [29]. This improvement enables the battery to perform better during charge and discharge cycles at high current densities. The high battery capacity and cycling stability observed in Cu-Zn(phen)S6 battery are attributed to the reversible nature of the Zn(phen)S6 material and its catalytic effect on the discharge products CuS/Cu2S. Ex-situ XPS analysis (Fig. 5 a–d) provides further evidence of these interactions. During the resting phase in a CuSO4 solution, characteristic peaks of Cu(I) at 932.81 eV and Cu(II) at 934.9 eV were observed in the Cu 2p XPS spectrum [30,31]. These peaks are associated with the presence of [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n and Cu9S5, respectively. In the sulfur 2p XPS spectrum, characteristic peaks for S0 (165.4/164.2 eV) and S− (163.5/162.9 eV) were observed, with the latter attributed to terminal chain sulfur in Zn(phen)S6. The presence of Zn(phen)S6 was further confirmed by Zn2+ peaks at 1045.2/1022.1 eV [32]. Upon complete discharge, new characteristic peaks for S2− (162.9/161.92 eV) [33] appeared in the S 2p spectrum, and the intensity of the S0 peaks decreased. The detection of Cu(I) peaks at 952.2/932.4 eV [30,31] indicates the transformation of sulfur from the broken sulfur chains into Cu2S, accompanied by the complete disappearance of the Zn2+ peaks. Upon reaching full charge, the Cu 2p region showed an enhanced Cu(II) peak, and the S− peaks reappeared in the S 2p region, while the energy levels in the Zn 2p region returned to their previous states. These results are consistent with the reversibility demonstrated in ex-situ XRD analyses. After 20 charge-discharge cycles, the Zn 2p peaks completely disappeared, whereas the N peaks were remained throughout, suggesting that within 20 cycles, Zn(phen)S6 was fully transformed into [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n . Meanwhile, During the discharge process, a Cu(0) peak appears at 951.5/932.2 eV, which disappears after recharging. To further investigate the mechanism of Zn(phen)S6 in the system, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed. Fig. S15(a, b) shows the distribution of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), indicating that the S6 2− chain can function both as an electron donor and an electron acceptor. This area is prone to electron transfer, potentially leading to the cleavage of the S6 2− chain. The electrostatic potential (ESP) map (Fig. S15c) reveals that the negative potential region of the S6 2− chain and the positive potential region of the phenanthroline can attract each other under suitable conditions, facilitating the formation of new chemical bonds. 2.3 Structural characterization and mechanistic investigation of [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4]n To investigate the role of [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n as the final transformation product in the Cu-S battery system, the complex was synthesized in bulk using established methods [34]. The crystal structure of the coordination polymer [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n complex is shown in Fig. S16. In this structure, the Cu2+ ion is coordinated in a [CuO4N2] octahedral geometry. The Cu2+ ion coordinates with two nitrogen atoms from the phenanthroline ligand (Cu–N = 2.010 Å), two oxygen atoms from sulfate groups (Cu–O = 2.675 Å), and two oxygen atoms from water molecules (Cu–O = 1.970 Å). Due to its novel double one-dimensional chains structures, these two one-dimensional chains run parallel to each other along the a-axis of the cell (Fig. S16a). Each one-dimensional chain is composed of distorted octahedral copper centers interconnected by bidentate sulfate ligands (Fig. S16b). Additionally, the stacking diagram of the complex molecules demonstrates that the structure is further stabilized through π-π stacking interactions (Fig. S16c) [35,36]. The correspondence between experimental and simulated PXRD values, as shown in Fig. S17(a), confirms the high purity of the synthesized crystals. Further analysis of the surface composition of the [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n complex was conducted using XPS (Fig. S17b–e), which consists of Cu, C, H, N, and S elements (Fig. S15b). Fig. S17(c) shows the central Cu2+ in the compound, with Cu 2p peaks fitted as a doublet at binding energies of 954.37 and 934.39 eV. Fig. S17(e) displays a doublet fitting of the S 2p XPS spectrum, corresponding to SO x compounds (168.80/167.62 eV) [37]. Elemental mapping images (Fig. S17g) further confirm the presence of Cu, S, and N within the crystal. Subsequently, the thermal stability of the complex was assessed under a nitrogen atmosphere using a TGA thermogram (Fig. S17f). The Cu-[Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n half-cell was assembled to investigate its mechanism within the Cu-S battery system. The CV curves of the half-cell (Fig. S18a) revealed reversible redox peaks during the charge-discharge processes, indicating the electrochemical activity of the material. However, rate performance tests at various current densities (Fig. S18b) showed limited capacity contribution. Subsequent XPS analysis of the cathode post-discharge (Fig. S18c–e) identified new peaks for Cu(0) at 952.66/932.24 eV in the Cu 2p XPS spectrum [30,31]. Further XRD testing of the cathode post charge-discharge (Fig. S18f) revealed no changes in the characteristic peaks of [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n . Therefore, the mechanism of the Cu-[Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n half-cell during the cycling process can be considered: Further verification through DFT calculations was conducted, as depicted in Fig. 6 . Fig. 6(a) shows that the HOMO orbitals are distributed over the phenanthroline ligand and the copper atom. This indicates that the copper atom is involved in the highest occupied molecular orbital, suggesting strong electronic interactions between the copper atom and the ligand. The electron distribution in the HOMO and LUMO (Fig. 6b) suggests that the copper ions within the compound can function as electron acceptors. In Fig. 6(c), the red regions represent areas of negative electrostatic potential, mainly concentrated on the water molecules and oxygen atoms, indicating their propensity to accept protons or cations. The blue regions represent areas of positive electrostatic potential, primarily focused on the phenanthroline ligand, suggesting that these areas are likely to donate electrons. Based on the results, the transformed crystal [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n functions effectively as a catalyst in the Cu-S battery system (Scheme 2 ). During the charging process, double electron transitions from Cu2S to [Cu(II)(phen)]2+, catalyzing the oxidation to form CuS and concurrently generating the zero-valent [Cu(0)(phen)]. On the other hand, during the discharge process, [Cu(0)(phen)] catalyzes the complete conversion of CuS to Cu2S in subsequent cycles, Concurrently, [Cu(0)(phen)] is reversibly oxidized back to [Cu(II)(phen)]2+. Therefore, [Cu(II)(phen)]2+ efficiently catalyzes the reversible transformation of CuS ↔ Cu2S within this catalytic cycle, significantly enhancing both the utilization of active materials and the electrochemical performance in the Cu-S battery system. Additionally, The binding energy indicates a stable association of Cu2+ within the [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n structure, suggesting significant thermodynamic stability and confirming the persistent presence of Cu2+ in this system (Fig. 6d, Table S1). Furthermore, the rigid potential energy surface scan reveals relatively small energy fluctuations and low energy barriers along the migration pathway, implying that Cu2+ can travel smoothly through this structure during discharge. Consequently, under suitable conditions, the [Cu(phen)(H2O) 2SO4] n framework could serve as an effective ion-transport channel, facilitating the release of Cu2+ from the anode and its subsequent migration to other regions (Fig. 6e) [38,39]. 2.4 Electrochemical performance of the Cu-S battery To differentiate the electrochemical differences between the two catalytic materials, we first verified the successful synthesis of the Zn(phen)S6/KB/S, [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S, and KB/S cathodes through relevant characterizations (Figs. S19 and S20a, b) and evaluated their electrochemical behavior in Cu-S batteries. CV at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 (Fig. 7 a) revealed a single reduction peak at ∼0.079 V in the first cycle, attributed to the pre-conversion of sulfur. The subsequent reversible electrochemical processes included four reduction peaks (at ∼0.194, ∼0.159, ∼0.126, and ∼0.064 V) and three oxidation peaks (at ∼0.179, ∼0.222, and ∼0.292 V). By correlating the redox peak positions with corresponding XRD measurements (Fig. S21), we confirmed that the first reduction peak in the initial cycle can be attributed to the final conversion of sulfur into Cu2S. As further charging proceeds, the Cu2S reflections disappear, and the characteristic peaks of Cu7S4, Cu39S28, and CuS subsequently emerge. Notably, the CV curves post-pre-conversion nearly overlapped, indicating high reversibility during the conversion processes. The CV profiles for [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S and KB/S cathodes also demonstrated similar transformation processes (Fig. S20c, f). As expected, the CV profiles of Zn(phen)S6/KB/S cathodes displayed smaller peak distance (Epp), indicating superior electrochemical kinetics and lower polarization compared to [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S and KB/S cathodes (Fig. 7b). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) further compared the resistance of Zn(phen)S6/KB/S, [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S, and KB/S cathodes (Fig. 7c). Notably, the Zn(phen)S6/KB/S electrode exhibited significantly lower charge transfer resistance than the S cathode, suggesting enhanced conductivity and facilitated electron transfer. Comparatively, the Zn(phen)S6/KB/S electrode exhibited the lowest polarization value (ΔE = 0.221 V), enhancing redox reactions more than KB/S (ΔE = 0.305 V) and [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S (ΔE = 0.276 V) cathodes (Fig. 7d). We tested the rate performance of Zn(phen)S6/KB/S and [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S cathodes in Cu-S batteries within a current density range of 1 to 10 A g−1 (Fig. 7e). As the current density increased to 1, 3, 5, and 10 A g−1, the reversible capacities gradually decreased to 1873, 1837, 1776, and1661 mAh g−1 for Zn(phen)S6/KB/S, and 1798, 1786, 1741, and 1627 mAh g−1 for [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S, respectively. When the current density was reduced to lower levels, the original capacities were significantly restored, demonstrating the high stability of the composite material electrodes. In contrast, the KB/S cathode exhibited inferior rate properties. Subsequent cycling performance tests at practical current densities of 10 and 20 A g−1 revealed high initial discharge capacities of 1798 mAh g−1 for Zn(phen)S6/KB/S and 1736 mAh g−1 for [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S at 10 A g−1, with capacity retention rates of 97.7% and 97.3% respectively after 1200 cycles (Fig. 7g). Even at 20 A g−1, the Zn(phen)S6/KB/S composite maintained a high capacity of 1157 mAh g−1 and a low capacity decay of 0.0091% after 1600 cycles, outperforming the [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S composite (892 mAh g−1 and 0.0154%) (Fig. 7i). This superior performance can be attributed to the smaller, more uniformly dispersed crystals of [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n derived in situ from Zn(phen)S6, enhancing the catalytic effect significantly. In contrast, the [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n crystals prepared ex-situ were larger and more prone to uneven physical dispersion during cathode fabrication, which could hinder their performance. Meanwhile, under the same high current densities of 10 and 20 A g−1, the KB/S cathode showed a rapid decline in initial discharge capacities from 1550 to 1291 mAh g−1, and from 1208 to 782 mAh g−1 respectively. These results highlight the robust performance and superior electrochemical stability of the Zn(phen)S6/KB/S cathode compared to both [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n /KB/S and KB/S cathodes. To validate the performance under extreme temperatures, we performed long-term cycling tests at 0 and 60 °C. It can be seen that the capacity remained nearly unchanged at low temperature, and after 300 cycles at 60 °C, the capacity still reached as high as 1237 mAh g−1 (Fig. S22). In addition, a Cu-S pouch cell (dimensions: 3 × 3 cm2, sulfur mass: ∼25 mg, sulfur loading: 2.8 mg cm−2) based on the Zn(phen)S6/KB/S cathode was fabricated. The Cu-S pouch cell exhibits excellent cycling stability, delivering an initial capacity of 1481 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 (Fig. S23). Considering the weight of all cell components and the operating voltage of 0.1 V, the practical energy density of the Cu-S pouch cell is estimated to be about 6 Wh kg−1 (Table S2). While the high capacity of Cu-S batteries is noteworthy, their low voltage significantly limits practical applications. To address this, we assembled a decoupled battery of Zn, ZnSO4||Zn(phen)S6/KB/S, CuSO4, utilizing an anion-exchange membrane to separate the battery into two sections (Fig. 7h) [40,41]. This decoupled battery not only boosted the initial voltage to approximately 1.2 V but also achieved a high initial discharge capacity of 2270 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.5 A g−1. To demonstrate the practical potential of Cu-S batteries in real-world applications, we connected button cells in series, successfully powering an light-emitting diode (LED) (Fig. 7j). These results unequivocally confirm the practicality of the Zn(phen)S6/KB/S cathode in high-capacity, long-life Cu-S batteries. Compared to other batteries reported in the field, the Zn(phen)S6/KB/S demonstrates competitively superior electrochemical performance (Fig. 7f and Table S3). 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we have demonstrated an effective strategy for developing aqueous Cu-S batteries using a multifunctional nano-capsular structured phenanthroline-metal complex catalyst electrode modified. Not only dose Zn(phen)S6 undergo reversible reactions, contributing significantly to the battery capacity, but also Zn2+ can co-deposit with Cu2+ on the anode surface, and through the synergistic effects of induction and displacement, making the anode surface deposition more uniform, enhancing electrode stability and thereby reducing battery polarization. During rest and cycling phases, Zn(phen)S6 crystals interact with Cu2+ ions to in situ form a catalyst, [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n , which encapsulates Zn(phen)S6. This complex ensures a more uniform distribution across the cathode surface. Importantly, [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n functions as a catalyst that not only undergoes redox reactions to provide additional electrons but, according to the rigid potential energy surface scan calculations, also serves as a copper-ion transport channel, effectively enhancing reaction kinetics. The Zn(phen)S6/KB/S composite cathode demonstrates excellent rate performance, delivering 1661 mAh g−1 at 10 A g−1 with a capacity retention of 97.7% after 1200 cycles. This multifunctional catalyst strategy, utilizing phenanthroline as an organic ligand, not only confirms the effectiveness of the catalyst but also highlights its potential to improve the electrochemical performance and lifespan of Cu-S batteries. Moreover, the exploration of novel catalytic materials in Cu-S batteries provides valuable insights into practical applications. Interestingly, in-situ UV characterization and the assembly of an organic Cu-S liquid battery reveal that Zn(phen)S6 can react with the discharge product Cu2S to induce the formation of previously unreported copper polysulfides, offering preliminary insights for future investigations into new reaction mechanisms. coredata.dc:description: Aqueous Cu-S batteries (ACSBs) offer a promising energy storage solution by leveraging the unique redox properties of Cu2+ ions, enabling high theoretical capacities through a four-electron transfer reaction. These advantages are coupled with inherent safety and low cost, making ACSBs a compelling alternative to traditional batteries. However, the practical application of ACSBs is hindered by the low conductivity of sulfur and the high energy barrier associated with phase transitions, which limit material utilization and reaction kinetics. Herein, we propose for the first time a multifunctional organic small-molecule polysulfide catalyst, Zn(phen)S6, and successfully convert them into nanocapsules that are homogeneously dispersed on the cathode surface, effectively increasing the catalytic active sites. Moreover, this complex undergoes reversible reactions during cycling, releasing zinc ions that form a dense protective layer on the anode during charging, effectively inhibiting dendrite growth. Meanwhile, Zn(phen)S6 interacts with Cu2+ ions to undergo an in-situ solid-state transformation into a novel catalyst, [Cu(phen)(H2O)2SO4] n . This catalyst not only accelerates electron transfer but also serves as an ion transport channel, significantly boosting reaction kinetics. This battery demonstrates exceptional stability, retaining 97.7% of its initial capacity after 1200 cycles at a high current density of 10 A g−1. Furthermore, it maintains an impressive capacity of 1157 mAh g−1 after 1600 cycles at 20 A g−1. This work provides pivotal insights into the design and application of molecular catalysts, opening new pathways for advancing Cu-S battery technologies.
